children.name: Managing the Commons
children.quote: The ‘tragedy of the commons’ refers to individual actors over-consuming or over-polluting natural resources in the quest to maximize their own, often short-term, benefit. —Beril Toktay
children.author: Dan Matisoff

children.name: Democratic Process
children.author: Richard Barke
children.quote: 'Good governance' has always been a challenge, as the Framers anticipated. People and groups will disagree about the purpose and proper role of government. To some, 'good governance' means active public involvement in rectifying injustice wherever it occurs; to others, there are important separations between pubic and private spheres of interest and action.

children.name: Voice & Agency
children.author: Christopher Le Dantec
children.school: School of Literature, Media, and Communication
children.quote: Voice and agency refer to the ways in which we seek out and engage with local expertise and experience.

children.name: Sustainable Urban Development
children.author: Bill Drummond
children.school: School of City and Regional Planning
children.quote: The concept of sustainable urban development provides a set of principles that can guide development and redevelopment of the built environment so that the needs of the present generation can be met without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.

children.name: Smart Cities
children.author: Jennifer Clark
children.quote: The ‘smart city’ refers to the increasing role of new digital technologies in understanding and addressing an array of problems facing contemporary cities.

children.name: Food-Energy-Water Nexus
children.author: Matthew Realff
children.quote: FEW systems can be define very broadly, according to the National Science Foundation 'incorporating physical processes (such as new technologies for more efficient resource utilization), natural processes (such as biogeochemical and hydrologic cycles), biological processes (such as agroecosystem structure and productivity), social/behavioral processes (such as decision making and governance), and cyber elements.'

children.name: Systems Thinking
children.quote: Systems thinking explicitly recognizing that there is a system with internal states and boundaries, with inputs and outputs, from and to, the environment placed outside the boundaries.  Systems thinking works to try to expand boundaries to include the phenomena that are relevant to the situation rather than excluding them to simplify study, and then tries to seek component behavior understanding that strips away the less important aspects for the question being asked.
children.author: Matthew Realff

children.name: Spatiotemporal Relations
children.author: Bryan Norton
children.quote: Attempts to achieve sustainability within hybrid human-natural systems must be sensitive to changes at multiple scales of space and time.

children.name: Lifecycle Analysis & Thinking
children.author: Matthew Realff
children.school2: Woodruff School of Mechanical Engineering; School of Industrial Design
children.quote: The idea is to evaluate the multi-dimensional impacts of delivering the unit of value not just at its point of delivery but also tracing supply chains required to deliver the value back to their points of origin, considering the impacts during the time the unit of value is being provided, and during any disposal or recycling.

children.name: Social & Environmental Determinants of Health
children.author: Suzy Harrington
children.quote: A holistic culture of health and well-being allows us to be the best we can be each moment, as we strive for excellence rather than perfection.

children.name: Rebound Effect
children.author: Matthew Realff
children.quote: A rebound effect is created when a perceived positive change in a system leads to another change that is regarded as negative, therefore leading to an offset in the benefits that were anticipated by causing the first change to happen.

children.name: Infrastructure: Physical, Technological, Social
children.author: Matthew Realff
children.quote: An infrastructure is defined as a network of human-made systems and processes that function cooperatively and synergistically to produce and distribute a continuous flow of essential goods and services.

children.name: Cultural, Linguistic & Biological Diversity
children.quote: Social justice on campus requires working toward inclusive excellence in all aspects of university.
children.author: Weissburg, Marc J

children.name: Equity and Climate
children.author: Alice Favero
children.quote: One does not automatically connect climate change with concerns about equity and social justice.  However, when one begins to think about the global and long-term dimensions of climate change as well as the asymmetry of benefits and costs of climate mitigation actions spatially and temporally, the connections become obvious.

children.name: Interconnectedness
children.author: Marc J Weissburg
children.quote: 'Interconnectedness' in ecology generally has to do with the network structure that describes how different species interact.

children.name: Technology for Social Good
children.author: Ellen Zegura
children.quote: Technology for Social Good refers to the use of technology – broadly engineering, applied science and computing-based artifacts, algorithm and techniques – towards addressing pressing social problems.

children.name: Social, Cultural & Environmental Context
children.author: Anne Pollock
children.school: School of Literature, Media, and Communication
children.quote: Science, Technology and Society (STS) is an interdisciplinary field of study that seeks to understand how science and technology shape society and culture and how society and culture, in turn, shape the development of science and technology.

children.name: Participatory Research
children.author: Christopher Le Dantec
children.school: School of Literature, Media, and Communication
children.quote: Participatory Research starts from the principle of research with, not research for.

children.name: Community Asset Mapping
children.author: Carl DiSalvo
children.school: School of Literature, Media, and Communication
children.quote: The value of mapping to sustainable communities is that is provides a familiar and concrete form to present meaningful data and orient stakeholders in regards to an issue.

children.name: Design Thinking
children.author: Carl DiSalvo
children.school: School of Literature, Media, and Communication
children.quote: Design thinking is a loose collection of methods and tactics abstracted from design practice and made applicable to issues, fields, and contexts generally thought of being outside of design.

children.name: Problem-based Learning
children.author: Wendy Newstetter
children.quote: Problem-based learning is an appropriate pedagogical approach for apprenticing students to the complexity of creating sustainable communities.

children.name: Ethnography
children.author: Carl DiSalvo
children.school: School of Literature, Media, and Communication
children.quote: Ethnography is the practice of structured observation and interpretation of culture and society.

children.name: Understanding Local History & Context
children.author: Anna Ioanes
children.school: School of Literature, Media, and Communication
children.quote: In studying how contemporary artists and writers resist and remake these stereotypes, however, we can also track how communities sustain themselves by resisting damaging stereotypes and fighting for environmental, economic, and representational justice.

children.name: Prototyping
children.author: Carl DiSalvo
children.school: School of Literature, Media, and Communication
children.quote: Prototyping is the activity of creating partial models of an artifact or system.

children.name: Digital Storytelling & Documentary Media
children.author: Nassim JafariNaimi
children.school: School of Literature, Media, and Communication
children.quote: The core strategy is co-design and conversation: bringing communities together in environments that facilitate collaborative problem solving through storytelling, prototyping and shared problem solving.

children.name: Visual Anthropology
children.author: Wayne Li
children.quote: Visual Anthropology is the concept of engaging communities and cultures in their context using photography and videography.x

children.name: Values-based Leadership
children.author: Bob Thomas
children.school: Institute of Leadership & Entrepreneurship (ILE), Scheller College of Business
children.quote: Values-based leadership means to lead others by remaining consistent with the leader’s beliefs.

children.name: Scientific Method
children.quote: In the sciences, discovery is often preceded by a line of inquiry known as the scientific method. This includes observation, hypothesis generation, experimental design, data analysis and hypothesis acceptance or rejection. Community members often observe problems that they hope research can help address, thereby participating in the scientific method by introducing the problem.
children.author: Jennifer Leavey

children.name: IPAT Equation
children.author: Bill Drummond
children.school: School of City and Regional Planning
children.quote: IPAT is an acronym for the equation of model that links sustainability outputs to three causal factors. The letters represent the basic form of the model, which is: Impact = Population * Affluence * Technology.

children.name: Ecological Footprint
children.author: Bill Drummond
children.quote: The ecological footprint provides a means to identify the gap between current practice and full sustainability at various levels from the neighborhood to the globe, and the method also allows the tracking of progress toward sustainability.

children.name: Social Entrepreneurship
children.author: Dori Pap
children.quote: Social Entrepreneurship is a new business model that is gaining popularity around the globe and is hoped to solve the issues that corporations and government alone can’t.

children.name: Results-based Accountability
children.author: Chris Burke
children.school: Govt. and Community Relations (GT Honor’s Program)
children.quote: Results Based Accountability (RBA) is a practice that established performance measures to achieve a mutually agreed upon result that seeks to improve communities.

children.name: GT as Living Lab
children.author: Jessica Rose
children.quote: The Living Laboratory concept will support applied learning for sustainability outcomes, utilizing the Georgia Tech campus as a place where real-world information is gathered, tested and improved.

children.name: GT as Anchor Institution
children.author: Chris Burke
children.quote: The Living Laboratory concept will support applied learning for sustainability outcomes, utilizing the Georgia Tech campus as a place where real-world information is gathered, tested and improved.

children.name: Cognitive Flexibility
children.quote: To some extent, cognitive flexibility is the Holy Grail when it comes to the desired out come of an effective learning experience.
children.author: Wendy C. Newstetter

children.name: Shared Value
children.author: Beril Toktay
children.quote: The concept of shared value recognizes that societal needs, not just conventional economic needs, define markets.

children.name: Doing Good in Your Neighborhood
children.author: Sheri Davis-Faulkner
children.school: Ivan Allen College of Liberal Arts
children.quote: An analytical view of the national landscape suggests that in the midst of urban crises, colleges and universities face three basic choices: exit, voice, and loyalty.
